snippet.textDisplay: Timeline: strock of 1am 12/25, spirit of Christmas past shows up. 2am 12/25, spirit of Christmas present shows up. snippet.textDisplay: The most obvious cinema sin was missed. Ebenezer Scrooge is so stingy he only has one employee, Bob Cratchit, who he’s refused to give a raise in years. But somehow in this version he’s got several rat bookkeepers. How much is this tightwad paying them? And if they are slaving away in the cold office and putting up with his abuse for free, why?
snippet.textOriginal: The most obvious cinema sin was missed. Ebenezer Scrooge is so stingy he only has one employee, Bob Cratchit, who he’s refused to give a raise in years. But somehow in this version he’s got several rat bookkeepers. How much is this tightwad paying them? And if they are slaving away in the cold office and putting up with his abuse for free, why?

snippet.textDisplay:
(1:15) Well, in The Chronicles of Narnia: The Magician's Nephew, it's clearly shown that Aslan grants intelligence to some individuals of certain species. Maybe it's the same thing in this reality?
(1:33) It could have been an accident.
(2:33 - 2:40) As a mouse owner, I can tell you that mice WILL eat a little cheese in their diets IF it's a dry cheese. out of my 171 total mice, only a small fraction (less than 10) regularly liked it and most of them preferred dry, shredded cheeses. There's too much fat in most cheeses for mice to eat it too much.
(9:12) Eh. That's why there's Boxing Day.
(14:40) 1.) The "gender pay gap" is more of a result of women bitching after the fact instead of learning how to negotiate salaries (and also not knowing the difference of the values of an actor's/actress' name) 2.) If your "money muscle" is your strength, use it. Screw those who bitch. "They just be hatin'."
(14:52) Lagomorph, not rodent. Hey, if you're going to be a nit-picking asshole, then so am I!
snippet.textOriginal:
(1:15) Well, in The Chronicles of Narnia: The Magician's Nephew, it's clearly shown that Aslan grants intelligence to some individuals of certain species.  Maybe it's the same thing in this reality?
(1:33) It could have been an accident.
(2:33 - 2:40) As a mouse owner, I can tell you that mice WILL eat *a little* cheese in their diets IF it's a dry cheese. out of my 171 total mice, only a small fraction (less than 10) regularly liked it and most of them preferred dry, shredded cheeses.  There's too much fat in most cheeses for mice to eat it too much.
(9:12) Eh.  That's why there's Boxing Day.
(14:40) 1.) The "gender pay gap" is more of a result of women bitching after the fact instead of learning how to negotiate salaries (and also not knowing the difference of the values of an actor's/actress' name) 2.) If your "money muscle" is your strength, use it.  Screw those who bitch.  "They just be hatin'."
(14:52) Lagomorph, not rodent.  Hey, if you're going to be a nit-picking asshole, then so am I!

snippet.textDisplay: I literally never thought before about how Scrooge made his money via moneylending. The actual ins and outs of it. We know he's good at it. Historically, moneylenders were often popular for people who needed to build things, and had no other avenues... Even the muslims loved having jews around when they needed to do some basic banking and were forbidden from charging each other interest
snippet.textOriginal: I literally never thought before about how Scrooge made his money via moneylending. The actual ins and outs of it. We know he's good at it. snippet.textDisplay: Scrooge is not dumb. He knows it's him, he knows he's the guy who's death everyone's happy about, he just doesn't want to admit it. 'Cause that would make it real, and to face the truth is hard. Like really hard. Like when there's no way of denying anymore you might cry hard. You can see and hear it in his tone from the moment he heard the men/pigs talk about his death. Brilliant acting.

snippet.textDisplay:
There's no such thing as "gender salary inequality".

And, first Scrooge is condemned for loving money more than people, and you sin him when he demonstrates that he loves people more than his money. Sure, he could have gone out, shot a goose and carried it to Bob Cratchet's house (thereby getting even more overt credit for his good deed).
But this way he A) has time to get dressed and get ready for Fred's party, B) provides an unexpected windfall for the boy and the poultry store owner who was probably going to have to throw out that goose/turkey (depending on version) and C) remains anonymous with his charitable contribution to Bob's Christmas.


But, I get it... Money bad. Not love of money; just money. Let's all live in a communist paradise and sing kum-by-ya as we all starve to death.
snippet.textOriginal:
There's no such thing as "gender salary inequality".

And, first Scrooge is condemned for loving money more than people, and you sin him when he demonstrates that he loves people more than his money. Sure, he could have gone out, shot a goose and carried it to Bob Cratchet's house (thereby getting even more overt credit for his good deed).
But this way he A) has time to get dressed and get ready for Fred's party, B) provides an unexpected windfall for the boy _and_ the poultry store owner who was probably going to have to throw out that goose/turkey (depending on version) and C) remains anonymous with his charitable contribution to Bob's Christmas.


But, I get it... Money bad. Not love of money; just money. Let's all live in a communist paradise and sing kum-by-ya as we all starve to death.

snippet.textOriginal: One of the many great things about Behind the Sins #BTeam is that you soon realize how much the writers begun to mimic one another because they are that connected.  It's like how all the characters on Archer eventually begin picking up Archers mannerisms.  Luv ya B Team!

snippet.textDisplay: I know the deal is to mock and all but Scrooge always knew who the dead man was he just didn’t want to accept it. It’s why he asks to see tenderness over death he’s hoping someone is actually morning him. Wiping the snow from his name is more him accepting that it’s him but removing the last veil of denial he can hide behind. To actually see his name and know that it is him they are all happy is dead.

snippet.textDisplay:
"Listen, husbands and wives and partners need to be able to have emotions in front of one another"

When are you dumbass moderns going to learn that your world is WORSE than the world preceding you?!

It's in YOUR world where everyone wears his heart on his sleeve that we have massive numbers of psychotic kids, adolescents and adults either drugged out of their minds, fragile snowflakes incapable of dealing with harsh realities, and or one bad day away from being Joker.

In the generations preceding your brilliant precious asses, people controlled their emotions so as not to add to the emotional burden of the loved ones around them. It's a dad's job to suppress his fears and put on a confident, optimistic "I can handle everything, so you can feel safe and secure" face. It's a mom's job to suppress her grief so as to be able to tend to the needs of her surviving children. Most men back in the day realized that nothing is contributed to solving a problem or dealing with a situation by becoming overtly emotional about it.

Only in the SJW-ruled 21st century is it considered a good thing for everyone to go around an emotional wreck, feeding everyone else's emotional wreckage.


Edit to add: I can recall only one time my dad overtly telling me "I love you". That was as he went into the hospital he never came out of.
Did I know he loved me without that?
Of course. Like the time, after a hard, hot day of laying brick when he stopped to play "kick the can" with me. Like the time I felt guilty at the A&W because I was for some reason starved for hot dogs; "if you keep eating them, I'll keep buying them".


Like the time my father, who never rode in a car he wasn't driving... fell asleep as I drove us home from work.
Like the time I fell off the scaffold, with people on the ground right next to where I fell, and him 40+ feet away... he was the one who picked me up almost as soon as I hit the ground.

Like the countless stories he made up to entertain me on the long drive to/from work each day.


People who love you don't have to tell you. They show you.

"Listen, husbands and wives and partners need to be able to have emotions in front of one another"

When are you dumbass moderns going to learn that your world is WORSE than the world preceding you?!

It's in YOUR world where everyone wears his heart on his sleeve that we have massive numbers of psychotic kids, adolescents and adults either drugged out of their minds, fragile snowflakes incapable of dealing with harsh realities, and or one bad day away from being Joker.

In the generations preceding your brilliant precious asses, people controlled their emotions so as not to add to the emotional burden of the loved ones around them. It's a dad's job to suppress his fears and put on a confident, optimistic "I can handle everything, so you can feel safe and secure" face. It's a mom's job to suppress her grief so as to be able to tend to the needs of her surviving children. Most _men_ back in the day realized that nothing is contributed to solving a problem or dealing with a situation by becoming overtly emotional about it.

Only in the SJW-ruled 21st century is it considered a good thing for everyone to go around an emotional wreck, feeding everyone else's emotional wreckage.


Edit to add: I can recall only one time my dad overtly telling me "I love you". That was as he went into the hospital he never came out of.
Did I know he loved me without that?
Of course. Like the time, after a hard, hot day of laying brick when he stopped to play "kick the can" with me. Like the time I felt guilty at the A&W because I was for some reason starved for hot dogs; "if you keep eating them, I'll keep buying them".


Like the time my father, who never rode in a car he wasn't driving... fell asleep as I drove us home from work.
Like the time I fell off the scaffold, with people on the ground right next to where I fell, and him 40+ feet away... he was the one who picked me up almost as soon as I hit the ground.

Like the countless stories he made up to entertain me on the long drive to/from work each day.


People who love you don't have to tell you. They show you.

snippet.textDisplay:
"...deserves to feel sad for once..."


Scrooge is sad all the time . It's what makes him a dickwad.

Also, in the original, Fred didn't hate him; Fred pitied him. Also also, in the George C Scott version, it makes it clear that Fred's wife mocks Scrooge, and Fred disagrees with it... "...as tight as..." "Your uncle Scrooge's wallet!"
snippet.textOriginal:
"...deserves to feel sad for once..."


Scrooge is sad _all the time_ . It's what makes him a dickwad. 

Also, in the original, Fred didn't hate him; Fred pitied him. Also also, in the George C Scott version, it makes it clear that Fred's _wife_ mocks Scrooge, and Fred disagrees with it... "...as tight as..."  "Your uncle Scrooge's wallet!"

snippet.textDisplay: Scrooge doesn't celebrate Christmas... but Scrooge doesn't live in China or Africa. Scrooge lives in 19th century London which is a culturally Christian place. So they have every business forcing Christmas down his throat. Because history has proven that culturally Christian places are much much better than other places. Which is why we have all those migrants fleeing the Christian west for refuge in the Islamic middle-east and atheist communist North Korea... If he wants to be anti-Christmas or anti-Christian, he can move someplace like Los Angeles... or modern-day London... oh, wait...

snippet.textDisplay:
"...mock his own blood for being poor?"


First, this is the 21st century, and don't for a minute pretend your a conservative; therefore "blood" means jack shit to you (because, if it meant anything to you, that would be raaaaaaaaaacist).

Second... he resents his nephew, remember? He resents his nephew for taking from him the one person who loved him unconditionally.
So, yes, he's going to be an asshole to his nephew, whom he probably raised, and who betrayed him by marrying a woman Scrooge didn't want him to marry.

snippet.textDisplay: After years of watching this on Christmas, I came up with an interesting question regarding the Muppets and a consequential answer to said question.  Why are most Muppets animals, with the few mutant exceptions who are just indistinguishable?  In a world where Muppets and humans coexist, there seems to be no racial or cultural difference between the interacting species.  Do they believe they are the same species?  Can they interbreed in this universe?  My theory: non-animal Muppets like Gonzo are the mixed kids of the human-Muppet universe.  Boom.
snippet.textOriginal: After years of watching this on Christmas, I came up with an interesting question regarding the Muppets and a consequential answer to said question.  Why are most Muppets animals, with the few mutant exceptions who are just indistinguishable?  In a world where Muppets and humans coexist, there seems to be no racial or cultural difference between the interacting species.  Do they believe they are the same species?  Can they interbreed in this universe?  My theory: non-animal Muppets like Gonzo are the mixed kids of the human-Muppet universe.  Boom.

snippet.textDisplay: TBH, I grew out of CinemaSins a long time ago, but I wanted to check this out because I was curious how they would approach the Muppets (did they do Labyrinth already? Guess I'm late then) and this was actually alright. I loved the humility in the beginning. Now I just need to wait for CinemaWins to approach something Muppet related (this, the Muppet Movie, Jason Segal's The Muppets, Follow That Bird, Labyrinth, Happytime Murderers, anything).

snippet.textDisplay: So, it's a great muppets movie, but the greatest? It's got great music, a fantastic performance from michael Caine, and the story is wonderful. But how much of that is because of the muppets? I dare say they took a backseat to everything else in the movie. It was the human elements that drove this one, versus Caper, manhattan, the self titled... I'll give you the greatest version of the Christmas carol.

It was the human elements that drove this one, versus Caper, manhattan, the self titled... I'll give you the greatest version of the Christmas carol.
